newsitem.title: GERMANY: Germany says first crude oil tranche 2.8 mln bbls.
newsitem.headline: Germany says first crude oil tranche 2.8 mln bbls.

text.p: The German Economics Ministry said on Monday the first tranche in its planned tender of strategic crude oil reserves in early August would be 450,000 cubic metres, or about 2.8 million barrels of oil.
"The oil will be sold in successive tranches each of 450,000 cubic metres from tank reserves," the ministry said in a statement.
"A typical average quality should be a mixture of 50 percent Iranian Heavy, 25 percent Arabian Light and 25 percent Kirkuk crude oil," it said.
Germany plans to hold a series of tenders to sell off its reserves starting in the week that begins on August 4, to raise around 400 million marks this year, a ministry spokeswoman said earlier.

Up to six tenders will be held between August and the end of 1997 as Germany unloads nearly two million tonnes of oil to try and lower its budget deficit to qualify for European economic and monetary union (EMU).
The sale of the oil is being organised by the Hamburg-based agency EBV.

Bonn said last week it would sell 7.3 million tonnes of crude oil, about 20 percent of total strategic reserves, as a way of cutting its budget deficit to keep within borrowing requirements laid down for EMU.
